Then you can at least get the optimizations that Inputstream can provide for reading blocks of data rather than one byte at a time. And you are not allocating that mega array like you currently have.
Question: How to run a mvn command from a java program?: :I am building a Java program for automating a procedure in my server side. Normally I cd to Desktop/GIT/ and use this maven command "mvn integration-test -DskipTests -P interactive -e".I am building a java program and I am trying to run that command line but so far I wasn't successful. So far, here is the code:public static void main(String[] args) throws FileNotFoundException {// TODO Auto-generated method stub Process theProcess = null;try  {      theProcess = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("mvn integration-test -DskipTests -P interactive -e");  } catch(IOException e)  {     System.err.println("Error on exec() method");     e.printStackTrace();    }// read from the called program's standard output stream  try  {     inStream = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader( theProcess.getInputStream()));       System.out.println(inStream.readLine());  }  catch(IOException e)  {     System.err.println("Error on inStream.readLine()");     e.printStackTrace();    }break;    }}in.close();}
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: ProcessBuilder
<<<code>>>: 
```java
ProcessBuilder builder = new ProcessBuilder(
    "bash", "-c", "cd Desktop/GIT/ && mvn integration-test -DskipTests -P interactive -e");
builder.redirectErrorStream(true);
Process process = builder.start();
BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(process.getInputStream()));
String line;
while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
    System.out.println(line);
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: Using ProcessBuilder is a more flexible way to start a process in Java. It allows you to specify the working directory, environment variables, and other details of the process. This way you can avoid issues with the current working directory and environment variables.

A: You can use the ProcessBuilder class to run the mvn command from your Java program. Here is an example:

```java
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ProcessBuilder builder = new ProcessBuilder(
                "bash", "-c", "cd Desktop/GIT/ && mvn integration-test -DskipTests -P interactive -e");
        builder.redirectErrorStream(true);
        try {
            Process process = builder.start();
            BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(process.getInputStream()));
            String line;
            while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
                System.out.println(line);
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
```

This code creates a new ProcessBuilder with the command to run the mvn command. The `redirectErrorStream(true)` method is used to redirect the error stream to the input stream, so that both streams can be read from the same object. The process is started with `builder.start()`, and the output of the process is read line by line and printed to the console.

Please replace `"bash"` with the path to your bash executable if it's not in the system's PATH.

Also, note that the `cd Desktop/GIT/` command in the mvn command won't affect the current working directory of the Java program. The Java program will still run in the directory where it was started. If you want to change the working directory of the Java program, you can use the `builder.directory(new File("path/to/directory"))` method before starting the process.
